subject: Re: [junit] JUnit and Java 1.5 'enum's
msgSnippet: Hey Jared, Nothing to be embarrassed about, it s an obscure failure that s always hard to debug.  Glad you figured it out. -- Cedric http://testng.org ... --
messageBody:
Hey Jared,

Nothing to be embarrassed about, it's an obscure failure that's always hard
to debug. Glad you figured it out.

--
Cedric
http://testng.org


On 10/19/06, Jared Warren <jared.warren@...> wrote:
>
> *insert official embarassment here*
>
> Just as I got your reply, I dug further back in the test logs and found a
> call to the ImageIcon constructor in the enum static initialization (just
> as
> you predicted.) The files referenced in the constructor weren't being
> copied into the classpath until after the tests were being run (d'oh),
> thus
> the static initialization block threw an exception and future attempts to
> load the class threw the NoClassDefFoundError.
>
> Thanks for your help!
> j.
>
> On 10/19/06, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
> >
> > On 10/18/06, Jared Warren <jared.warren@...<
> jared.warren%40gmail.com>>
> > wrote:
> > >
> > > Yeah, that's certainly what I thought....
> > >
> > > But all of my other tests pass, and the classes are all generated by
> the
> > > same compiler call, and the "destdir" is the same for all of them. (In
> > > fact, the stack trace includes classes that are in the same package
> and
> > > directory as the 'enum' that's causing the NoClassDefFoundError to be
> > > thrown.
> >
> > Not sure what else to tell you, except to point out that you're looking
> at
> > at NoClassDefFound, and not ClassNotFound.
> >
> > NoClassDefFound is typically thrown when a class can't complete its
> > initialization (for example, in a static block). Do you have static
> > blocks? Are they referencing external classes?
> >
> > --
> > Cédric
> > http://testng.org
> >
> > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
> >
> >
> >
>
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
